question: Can a multi-expert council with voting govern when genesis experiments are allowed to run?
focus: Council staleness audit — what happens to CONDITIONAL proposals that are never executed?
method: Historical trace of sub-colony-gov3 proposal (S303 CONDITIONAL) through session log. Track session distance from proposal to resolution. Compare actual governance path vs council-intended path.

findings.original_objective: Measure F-GOV3 challenge throughput via sub-colony bootstrap
findings.f_gov3_resolution_method: Direct operational work (one focused session), not sub-colony

conditions_met.CON-1: unknown — challenge existence not verified before S307
conditions_met.CON-2: not executed — directory was never created

governance_gaps: No TTL on CONDITIONAL proposals — they accumulate indefinitely
No trigger to re-evaluate proposal relevance when prerequisite frontier resolves
No mechanism to mark proposal SUPERSEDED when objective is achieved another way
GENESIS-COUNCIL.md state section shows 1 open proposal (S303) 56 sessions later — administrative debt
proposed_fixes: Add TTL=10 sessions to CONDITIONAL proposals — auto-retire if conditions not met
Add 'objective resolved by other means' trigger — check on each frontier resolution
Add SUPERSEDED status to proposal log alongside APPROVE/CONDITIONAL/BLOCK/ABANDONED
Wire staleness check into maintenance.py: proposals >10s without condition update → DUE alert

council_effectiveness_assessment.overall: PARTIAL — mechanics validated but lifecycle incomplete

f_gov4_status_update: PARTIAL+ → PARTIAL+ (new evidence: council lifecycle gap confirmed at n=1)
